docs.abstract: Despite the president’s slow performance on the coronavirus and his series of falsehoods, some independent voters and Democrats are giving him a measure of credit for his handling of the crisis.
docs.snippet: Despite the president’s slow performance on the coronavirus and his series of falsehoods, some independent voters and Democrats are giving him a measure of credit for his handling of the crisis.
docs.lead_paragraph: Justin Penn, a Pittsburgh voter who calls himself politically independent, favored Joseph R. Biden Jr. in a matchup with President Trump until recently. But the president’s performance during the coronavirus outbreak has Mr. Penn reconsidering.

headline.main: Who Are the Voters Behind Trump’s Higher Approval Rating?
headline.print_headline: During Crisis, Trump’s Approval Gets Boost From Crucial Voters

byline.original: By Trip Gabriel and Lisa Lerer

docs.abstract: As the virus disrupts the campaign, G.O.P. officials are taking their cue from President Trump, while Joe Biden said “it’s hard to envision” the Democrats holding an in-person convention in July.
docs.snippet: As the virus disrupts the campaign, G.O.P. officials are taking their cue from President Trump, while Joe Biden said “it’s hard to envision” the Democrats holding an in-person convention in July.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Taking their cue from President Trump, Republicans at every level of the party are pushing ahead with plans to put on their national convention this summer and provide Mr. Trump the kind of gauzy coronation he seeks.

headline.main: Democrats Fear for Their Convention. For Republicans, ‘The Show Must Go On.’
headline.print_headline: Hold Conventions? Even Here, Parties Disagree

byline.original: By Reid J. Epstein and Annie Karni

docs.abstract: With a broad coalition, Joseph R. Biden Jr. defeated Bernie Sanders in Florida, Illinois and Arizona, in a rout that could add to pressure on Mr. Sanders to end his campaign.
docs.snippet: With a broad coalition, Joseph R. Biden Jr. defeated Bernie Sanders in Florida, Illinois and Arizona, in a rout that could add to pressure on Mr. Sanders to end his campaign.
docs.lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. easily defeated Senator Bernie Sanders in three major primaries on Tuesday, all but extinguishing Mr. Sanders’s chances for a comeback, as anxious Americans turned out to vote amid a series of cascading disruptions from the coronavirus pandemic.

headline.main: Biden Sweeps Three States and Takes Commanding Lead, as Virus Reshapes American Politics
headline.print_headline: Biden Sweeps 3 States on Chaotic Day of Voting

byline.original: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

docs.abstract: They are among the senators facing criticism for offloading investments before the market tumbled. Here’s a look at the political consequences they might face.
docs.snippet: They are among the senators facing criticism for offloading investments before the market tumbled. Here’s a look at the political consequences they might face.
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Richard M. Burr, Republican of North Carolina, and Senator Kelly Loeffler, Republican of Georgia, have come under fire for selling off stocks collectively worth millions of dollars ahead of the economic downturn that has coincided with the coronavirus pandemic.

headline.main: Kelly Loeffler and Richard Burr Were Briefed on Coronavirus. Then They Sold Stocks. What Now?

docs.abstract: With the coronavirus as a backdrop, and with no audience in attendance, the two Democrats were at times feisty discussing their differences over health care. Mr. Biden also committed to choosing a woman as a running mate.
docs.snippet: With the coronavirus as a backdrop, and with no audience in attendance, the two Democrats were at times feisty discussing their differences over health care. Mr. Biden also committed to choosing a woman as a running mate.
docs.lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Bernie Sanders called for vastly more aggressive government action to battle the coronavirus but split over some of the details along familiar ideological lines on Sunday night, as the two Democrats tangled over the right to lead their party into a campaign overshadowed by the pandemic inflicting havoc on the country’s economy and its social fabric.

headline.main: Biden and Sanders Fight Over Policy and Records in Head-to-Head Debate
headline.print_headline: Two Rivals Take On Outbreak, and Each Other

byline.original: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

docs.abstract: It was a primary sweep, but the future is far from clean and tidy. This is your morning tip sheet.
docs.snippet: It was a primary sweep, but the future is far from clean and tidy. This is your morning tip sheet.
docs.lead_paragraph: A poll worker wore gloves for protection against the coronavirus outside a voting site at Woodmere Park in Venice, Fla.

headline.main: On Politics: Biden Gets Out the Broom

docs.abstract: The Biden campaign and a long list of surrogates are striving to engage progressive Democrats who have so far been cool to Mr. Biden’s presidential bid.
docs.snippet: The Biden campaign and a long list of surrogates are striving to engage progressive Democrats who have so far been cool to Mr. Biden’s presidential bid.
docs.lead_paragraph: Through conversations on Capitol Hill, engagement with local activists and policy nods toward Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign and its allies are ramping up overtures to progressives, aiming to improve Mr. Biden’s standing with a key part of the Democratic coalition in an effort to unite the party around his potential nomination.

headline.main: The Left Is Still Leery of Biden. Here’s How He’s Reaching Out to Them.
headline.print_headline: Biden and His Supporters Make Delicate Overtures to a Leery Left

byline.original: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan

docs.abstract: As President Trump holds daily briefings, Mr. Biden has kept a low profile, worrying Democrats who feel the president needs to be challenged more robustly.
docs.snippet: As President Trump holds daily briefings, Mr. Biden has kept a low profile, worrying Democrats who feel the president needs to be challenged more robustly.
docs.lead_paragraph: With President Trump providing daily televised briefings and governors like Andrew M. Cuomo emerging as national leaders during the coronavirus pandemic, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is still grappling with how to position himself as a prominent voice on a crisis that is pushing traditional politics to the background.

headline.main: Joe Biden Is Trying to Be Heard on the Virus. Can He Break Through?
headline.print_headline: Biden, Offstage During a Crisis,  Strains to Make Himself Heard

byline.original: By Thomas Kaplan and Alexander Burns

docs.abstract: It turns out that a global pandemic can really shake up our politics.
docs.snippet: It turns out that a global pandemic can really shake up our politics.
docs.lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline.print_headline: A ‘Big Government’ Response, but Is It a Sign of a Broader Change to Come?

docs.abstract: The former vice president had the Super Tuesday of his dreams, winning in places he hasn’t even set foot in recently.
docs.snippet: The former vice president had the Super Tuesday of his dreams, winning in places he hasn’t even set foot in recently.
docs.lead_paragraph: The scene, on its face, might not have been surprising a year ago: Joe Biden — appraised among Democrats as a decent man and affable sidekick to the party’s most popular figure — racking up primary victories and having fun talking about it.

headline.main: Democrats Decide That Joe Biden, as Risky as He Ever Was, Is the Safest Bet
headline.print_headline: A Wobbling Moderate Suddenly Hits His Stride
